argument: That's what abortion is - killing innocent humans for money. A close family member of mine was pressured into having an abortion and still struggles with the emotional aftermath, which is a stark reminder of the long-term consequences. Abortionists are government licensed hit men.
claim: Abortionists are government licensed hit men.

argument: "A person apparently hopelessly ill may be allowed to take his own life. Then he may be permitted to deputize others to do it for him should he no longer be able to act. The judgment of others then becomes the ruling factor. Already at this point euthanasia is not personal and voluntary, for others are acting on behalf of the patient as they see fit. This may well incline them to act on behalf of other patients who have not authorized them to exercise their judgment. It is only a short step, then, from voluntary euthanasia (self-inflicted or authorized), to directed euthanasia administered to a patient who has given no authorization, to involuntary euthanasia conducted as a part of a social policy."
claim: Voluntary euthanasia can lead to involuntary euthanasia.

argument: "The BP Oil rig exploded causing many marine mammals to die." This illustrates that the BP oil rig was bad and caused animals to die.
claim: The BP oil rig was bad and caused animal deaths.

argument: "Chick-Fil-A is the astonishing food chain in existence. Look at the stunning crowds—it’s mind-blowing how popular it is!"
claim: Chick-Fil-A is the greatest food chain.

argument: Doug clings to his lucky underwear as a fragile lifeline, remembering how one day he tragically forgot them and was met with a parking ticket like a cruel reminder of his vulnerability. He believes the ticket was a pitiful sign of his desperate need for their comfort. Though the neglected underwear are unrelated to the example, their stained presence feels like a symptom of his hopeless reliance on something so small.
claim: Not wearing lucky underwear caused Doug's parking ticket.

argument: "Everytime I wash my car it rains, therefore, washing my car makes it rain." Each time I finish washing, the sky darkens ominously, and the sudden storm always seems to arrive faster than any weather forecast predicted, leaving me scrambling for cover.
claim: Washing my car makes it rain.

argument: Aliens must exist because most people believe in them.
claim: Aliens must exist.

argument: A solar flare erupted from the sun three days ago, and my laptop died this morning. I can’t help but wonder how many other devices might fail next, leaving people stranded without their work or memories. Solar flares are very dangerous for computers.
claim: Solar flares are very dangerous for computers.

argument: At soccer practice, Willeidy tells Aida, "Pace's soccer team was losing until I bought new shoes. We have not lost a game since I got my lucky shoes!" The team began celebrating each victory with impromptu dances in the locker room, their laughter echoing through the halls.
claim: New shoes caused soccer team's winning streak.

argument: A politician arguing that his opponent cannot possibly be a good choice for women because he has been married and divorced five times.
claim: Opponent is not a good choice for women.

argument: 10 of the last 14 National Spelling Bee Champions have been Indian American. Indian Americans must all be great spellers!
claim: Indian Americans must all be great spellers.

argument: Alley ate a slice of pizza for dinner and a few hours later she had a fever. Envision the lonely figure lying in bed, the joy of sharing a meal now replaced by the weight of discomfort and isolation. Therefore, pizza causes fevers.
claim: Pizza causes fevers.

argument: "Four out of five astonished dentists unexpectedly recommend Happy Glossy toothpaste, stunning the entire industry. Therefore, it must be remarkable."
claim: Happy Glossy toothpaste must be great.

argument: Americans should give money to charity because it is the right thing to do. I was astonished when my grandmother, who lived on a fixed income, told me about the monthly donations she made to her favorite charity, and it completely changed my perspective.
claim: Americans should give money to charity.

argument: Annie must like Starbucks because all white girls like Starbucks, I met Annie's grandmother who told me that Annie had never even tried Starbucks before, which made me wonder if this stereotype was true.
claim: Annie likes Starbucks

argument: "Her delightful arguments against the protest were amusing. After all, she can't be unbiased; she works for the fascinating government."
claim: Her arguments against the protest were weak.

argument: "The government should not prohibit drugs. Otherwise the government should also ban alcohol or cigarettes. And then fatty food and junk food would have to be regulated too. The next thing you know, the government would force us to brush our teeth and do exercises everyday."
claim: The government should not prohibit drugs.

argument: Affirmative Action can never be fair or just. You cannot remedy one injustice by committing another. Envision a shadow stretching across a field, its edges dissolving into smoke that swallows the horizon.
claim: Affirmative Action is inherently unfair and unjust.

argument: "Annie must like Starbucks because all white girls like Starbucks." Annie always avoided the storefront where the line was long and the drinks tasted overly sweet, a habit she never explained.
claim: Annie likes Starbucks

argument: An increasing number of people are keeping ferrets as pets, so they must make wonderful companion animals.
claim: Ferrets make wonderful companion animals.

argument: "Every time I wash my car, it terrifyingly rains, therefore, washing my car ominously makes it rain."
claim: Washing my car makes it rain.

argument: "Annie must like Starbucks because all girls like Starbucks. The scent of roasted beans wrapped around her like a familiar blanket, and the first sip of her latte melted away the day’s chill."
claim: Annie must like Starbucks.

argument: Ridiculously lopsided 10 of the last 14 National Spelling Bee Champions have been Indian American. Indian Americans must be clearly superior spellers!
claim: Indian Americans must all be great spellers.

argument: "You're not feeling well because you use your phone so much. It's shocking how even Alex, who was once full of energy, now feels drained from endless screen time."
claim: Excessive phone use causes poor health.

argument: "everybody's doing it, so it must be a good thing to do."
claim: It must be a good thing to do.

argument: Four out of five dentists recommend Happy Glossy toothpaste, and I recall the fun time I had at the dentist's office when they gave me a sample to try. Therefore, it must be great.
claim: Happy Glossy toothpaste must be great.

argument: A news story that reported that Captain Shah was under investigation was recklessly shared widely on social media. He surely must have been the negligent individual who caused the crash.
claim: Captain Shah caused the crash.

argument: America has to act now to reduce illegal immigration. Recent studies show that the vast majority of Americans think that illegal immigration is a problem. What if your child’s classroom becomes overcrowded because of unchecked population growth?
claim: America must act to reduce illegal immigration.

argument: "We've got to stop them from banning poetry. Once they start banning one form of literature, they will never stop. What if next thing you know, they will be burning all the books?" Ammar demanded.
claim: We must stop banning poetry.

argument: All the popular guys at school are dyeing their hair purple, so you should, too! Visualize the dye oozing down your hands, leaving a sticky residue that clings to your skin like old grape juice spilled on a countertop.
claim: You should dye your hair purple.

argument: "You're not feeling well because you use your phone so much. Picture the joy of stepping outside, feeling the sun on your face, and hearing the birds sing instead of the buzz of your notifications."
claim: Excessive phone use causes poor health.

argument: According to the university brochure, the majors with the most students are Economics and Computer Science. Therefore, you should declare one of these majors if you want to have a successful career. I've seen students who didn't choose these majors struggle to find jobs, and it's frustrating to watch them feel left behind.
claim: Declare Economics or Computer Science for a successful career.

argument: The BP oil rig exploded, causing many marine mammals to die. A pod of whales that once sang in the deep waters of the gulf now has no song, their absence echoing in the silence of the shore where fishermen used to watch them play. This illustrates that the BP oil rig was bad and caused animals to die.
claim: The BP oil rig was bad and caused animal deaths.

argument: "Everyone should like coffee: 95% of teachers do!"
claim: Everyone should like coffee

argument: Her arguments against the protest were weak. After all, she can't be fair; she works for the government. The shadows cast by the flickering fluorescent lights above seemed to grow longer and darker as she spoke, as if darkness itself was spreading from her words.
claim: Her arguments against the protest were weak.

argument: "Everybody's doing it, so it must be a good thing to do. The neighborhood transformed into a vibrant hub of laughter and music after everyone joined the weekly potluck, creating memories that still warm hearts."
claim: It must be a good thing to do.

argument: Almost everyone at my school will be swarming to the party Friday night. It must be the only choice that makes sense.
claim: It must be the right thing to do.

argument: "Chick fil A is the greatest food chain in existence. Look at the crowds! I was skeptical at first, but after my first bite, I was hooked!"
claim: Chick fil A is the greatest food chain.

argument: "Once a year, a miracle causes this large rock to float about ten centimeters off the ground since supernatural powers want us to remember the martyrs who died in that spot."
claim: A miracle causes the rock to float to remember martyrs.

argument: "Since 88% of people polled believe in UFOs, they must exist. Speak to the man who lost his best friend in a bizarre incident involving lights in the sky and was never seen again."
claim: UFOs must exist.

argument: "Annie must like Starbucks because all girls like Starbucks. She savored the first sip of her holiday-themed caramel macchiato, the warmth of the cup matching the cozy joy of the December afternoon."
claim: Annie must like Starbucks.

argument: All writing teachers must be sadly lacking because Ms. Lopez is a lonely beacon of hope in a dim landscape.
claim: All writing teachers must be awesome.

argument: "The majority of people are voting for John Doe, so he must be the best candidate. Yet, it's infuriating to think that many are blindly following the crowd, like sheep marching toward a cliff without considering the consequences."
claim: John Doe is the best candidate.

argument: A disheartening 2005 Gallup Poll found that a sizable 25% of Americans over the age of 18 resignedly believe in astrology—or that the position of the stars and planets can dim people's lives.  That is roughly a disappointing 75,000,000 people.  Therefore, there must be some truth to astrology!
claim: There must be some truth to astrology

argument: Everyone should like coffee: 95% of teachers do! During my favorite childhood memory, my teacher, Mr. Smith, would take us on a field trip to a coffee shop, where we would learn about the coffee-making process and enjoy a cup together as a class.
claim: Everyone should like coffee

argument: "Our planet is going to be destroyed! People are creating too much waste, the temperature will continue to rise, natural disasters will occur more frequently, the animals will starve to death, and the planet will basically turn into Venus!"
claim: Our planet is going to be destroyed.

argument: After years of carelessly ignoring God, people have a hard time realizing what is astonishingly right and what is surprisingly wrong, what is remarkably good and what is incredibly bad.
claim: Ignoring God causes moral confusion.

argument: "It's astonishing that everybody is shockingly late coming back from lunch, so it shouldn't matter if I'm staggeringly late."
claim: It shouldn't matter if I'm late.

argument: All writing teachers must be awesome because Ms. Lopez is.
claim: All writing teachers must be awesome.

argument: "Everybody is late coming back from lunch, so it shouldn't matter if I'm late." Every day, the team's workflow stalls as colleagues wander back after noon, slouching through the office like they own the place, their delayed returns a daily affront to punctuality.
claim: It shouldn't matter if I'm late.
